awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Nanoscale Synthesis and Imaging of Novel Topological Phases
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
Materials can often be categorized based on how electrons within them behave. For example, in metals, electrons are free to move around and conduct electricity, while in insulators, they cannot. "Topological materials" are a new family of materials that cannot be classified in such a simple manner. For instance, a prototypical topological material called a "topological insulator" (TI) is an insulator in the bulk, but exhibits metallic behavior on the surface. In other words, only the surface of a TI is allowed to conduct electricity. Moreover, electrons on the surface of a TI can have zero mass and behave like relativistic particles. A theoretical framework for several novel types of topological materials has emerged in recent years, each one hosting new exotic properties, but experiments have struggled to fully catch up with these predictions. This project combines two advanced atomic-scale techniques to create and characterize new topological materials: (1) molecular beam epitaxy to create the materials a single atomic layer at a time, and (2) scanning tunneling microscopy to visualize their atomic and electronic structure. The project aims to provide a fundamental advancement in the understanding of topological materials, as well as to craft new materials for their eventual use in technology, such as in spintronics and quantum computing. The education goals of this project utilize the principal investigator's expertise in materials growth and microscopy imaging, and are targeted to impact a wide range of students, including middle school, high school, undergraduate and graduate students. The specific efforts include establishing outreach events in local K-12 schools, participating in Research Science Institute summer program, organizing science talks at the university level, and developing courses focused on state-of-the-art synthesis and microscopy techniques.

Technical Abstract:
The past few decades have seen the emergence of several classes of materials with extraordinary physical properties, such as high-temperature superconductors, colossal magnetoresistance materials and 2D systems such as graphene. Topological materials - systems hosting novel electronic states whose existence and properties are specified by a topological invariant - are the most recent addition to the list. Prototypical topological materials are topological insulators, systems characterized by an odd Z2 topological invariant calculated from the electronic band structure. Even though topological insulators are bulk insulators, the topology of the band structure dictates the existence of gapless metallic electronic states at their boundary, occupied by massless Dirac fermions that are protected by symmetry. Recently, a theoretical framework for several new classes of topological systems has emerged, including topological crystalline insulators, topological superconductors and Weyl semimetals. However, experiments have struggled to fully catch up with these predictions, due to both synthesis and characterization bottlenecks. This project uses a rare combination of molecular beam epitaxy and spectroscopic-imaging scanning tunneling microscopy to explore new pathways for discovering and manipulating topological phases. Specifically, the project aims to create new topological phases in thin films of (Pb,Sn)Te family of semiconductors, by exploring different film thicknesses, substrates, doping and strain. Nanoscale spectroscopic characterization down to ~400 mK base temperature in variable magnetic field allows the explorations of topological phases with superior spatial and energy resolution. The education goals of this project are targeted to impact a wide range of students via establishing outreach events in local middle school and high schools, participating in Research Science Institute summer program, organizing science talks for students at the university level, and developing courses focused on state-of-the-art synthesis and microscopy techniques.

por.por_cntn:
Research under this award focused on realizing, tuning and exploring topological and correlated electronic phases in quantum materials at the atomic length scales using a combination of scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy (STM/S) and molecular beam epitaxy (MBE).

The initial focus of the award was layer-by-layer creation and imaging of topological superconductor heterostructures, superconducting materials with exotic topological electronic states at the surface. This was done by interfacing thin films of non-superconducting topological materials with various superconducting substrates using molecular beam epitaxy. A leading theory predicted that these heterostructures could host Majorana fermions, exotic quasiparticles that are their own anti-particles, which could potentially be used for down-the-line quantum computing applications. We successfully induced superconductivity in topological insulator Bi2Te3 and topological crystalline insulator SnTe by proximity to high-temperature superconductor Fe(Te,Se), thus establishing a new platform for the potential realization of topological superconductivity and Majorana modes at higher temperatures.

Related to this, during our explorations of using high-temperature superconductors in MBE heterostructure growth, we discovered that we can control charge carrier concentration, or 'doping', by annealing the material in vacuum. This process opened up the possibility of achieving a substantial doping range at the surface that is difficult to achieve in the interior of the material. The effort led to a detection of a new unidirectional charge ordered state in an insulating cuprate superconductor. Such state was theoretically predicted decades ago, and our experiments provided elusive support for the existence of the insulating 'charge-stripe' phase using STM.

Another thrust was to investigate how to deform materials and simultaneously quantify atomic distortions and the electronic response using STM. We established a new strain method compatible with STM to deform prototypical charge density wave (CDW) material NbSe2, and discovered new emergent CDWs. We also investigates the effects of strain in a range of other materials. In Fe-based high-temperature superconductors in particular, we explored the interplay of structural deformations, suppression of superconductivity and spontaneous breaking of rotation symmetry in the electronic structure called electronic 'nematic phase. We found that when the material is at the cusp of becoming 'nematic', tiny amounts of strain can dramatically suppress superconductivity in Fe(Te,Se). Overall, we established a foundation for atomic-scale strain application and concomitant electronic characterization of materials using STM.

Lastly, we investigated a newly discovered family of kagome superconductors AV3Sb5, which attracted tremendous interest in the community as an unusual family of superconductors with possible 'orbital' magnetism, where electrons spontaneously synchronize their orbital motion. In these materials, we discovered a cascade of electronic states, including surprising CDW states, emerging as the system is cooled to become a superconductor. Interestingly, we found substantial unidirectionality of the electronic structure with a single preferred lattice direction. In other words, out of the three possible crystalline directions, electrons in these materials like to select one preferred direction.

Broader impacts of the award include providing training and professional development opportunities to numerous undergraduate and graduate students. The award also enabled participation of multiple high-school students working as summer interns in the lab. The effort was made to provide lab tours to various groups of K-12 student visitors. The PI contributed as a faculty mentor for Sigma Pi Sigma and Society of Physics Students at Boston College for the first two years of the award. As a part of this endeavor, the PI organized seminar talks and a poster session targeted towards advertising contemporary physics research comprehensible at an undergraduate level to the Boston College community.
